questions.question: She wasn't .......................... to be discouraged by some of her teachers.
She soon grew ......................... to manage without a hearing aid.
The task was ............................ for any teenager fresh from a Scottish farm.
questions.description: Enough is an adverb. It goes after the adjective or adverb modified by it.

questions.question: Rahul was .......................... busy that he could not talk to me.
The car is ........................... to seat six people.
questions.description: The expression 'too large' has a negative meaning. 'Large enough' shows adequacy.

questions.question: He walked ............................ fast that I could not catch up with him.
She is ............................ to buy a car.
questions.description: When enough is used as an adverb, it goes after the adjective or adverb modified by it.  The expression 'rich enough' has a positive meaning whereas the expression 'too rich' has a negative meaning.

questions.question: None of the mangoes is .............................. to be eaten.
questions.description: Enough goes after the adjective modified by it.

questions.question: She has ............................. many students in her class that she cannot give them individual attention.
questions.description: Note the pattern 'so...that'. We cannot use a that-clause after very.

questions.question: He is ................................ to solve the problem.
questions.description: The expression 'intelligent enough' has a positive meaning whereas the expression 'too intelligent' has a negative meaning.

questions.question: The light was not .............................. for one to see things clearly.
questions.description: 'Bright enough' has a positive meaning. It shows adequacy. 'Too bright' has a negative meaning.
